data.title: Nobel Prize for Literature
data.meta_description: This page lists the Nobel prize winners to date. The Nobel Prize in Literature has been awarded almost annually since 1901. It is intended to go to an author who has produced outstanding work "in an ideal direction." While individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is primarily based on an‚Ä¶
data.text:
‚ùÆ Poetry & Prose ‚ùÆ Books / People

The Nobel Prize in Literature has been awarded almost annually since 1901. It is intended to go to an author who has produced outstanding work ‚Äúin an ideal direction.‚Äù While individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is primarily based on an author‚Äôs body of work as a whole.

‚Äî ¬ß ‚Äî

Sully Prudhomme

1901

‚Äî French

‚Äî Poetry

Ren√© Fran√ßois Armand (Sully) Prudhomme (1839‚Äì1907) was a French poet and essayist. In giving the award the committee said, ‚Äúin special recognition of his poetic composition, which gives evidence of lofty idealism, artistic perfection and a rare combination of the qualities of both heart and intellect.‚Äù

1902 / Theodor Mommsen

‚Äúthe greatest living master of the art of historical writing, with special reference to his monumental work A History of Rome‚Äù

‚Äî history, law

1903 / Bj√∏rnstjerne Bj√∏rnson

‚Äúas a tribute to his noble, magnificent and versatile poetry, which has always been distinguished by both the freshness of its inspiration and the rare purity of its spirit‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, novel, drama

1904 / Fr√©d√©ric Mistral

‚Äúin recognition of the fresh originality and true inspiration of his poetic production, which faithfully reflects the natural scenery and native spirit of his people, and, in addition, his significant work as a Proven√ßal philologist‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, philology

1905 / Henryk Sienkiewicz

‚Äúbecause of his outstanding merits as an epic writer‚Äù

‚Äî novel

1906 / Giosu√® Carducci

‚Äúnot only in consideration of his deep learning and critical research, but above all as a tribute to the creative energy, freshness of style, and lyrical force which characterize his poetic masterpieces‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

1907 / Rudyard Kipling

‚Äúin consideration of the power of observation, originality of imagination, virility of ideas and remarkable talent for narration that characterize the creations of this world-famous author‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, poetry

1908 / Rudolf Christoph Eucken

‚Äúin recognition of his earnest search for truth, his penetrating power of thought, his wide range of vision, and the warmth and strength in presentation with which in his numerous works he has vindicated and developed an idealistic philosophy of life‚Äù

‚Äî philosophy

1909 / Selma Lagerl√∂f

‚Äúin appreciation of the lofty idealism, vivid imagination and spiritual perception that characterize her writings‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story

1910 / Paul von Heyse

‚Äúas a tribute to the consummate artistry, permeated with idealism, which he has demonstrated during his long productive career as a lyric poet, dramatist, novelist and writer of world-renowned short stories‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, drama, novel, short story

1911 / Maurice Maeterlinck

‚Äúin appreciation of his many-sided literary activities, and especially of his dramatic works, which are distinguished by a wealth of imagination and by a poetic fancy, which reveals, sometimes in the guise of a fairy tale, a deep inspiration, while in a mysterious way they appeal to the readers‚Äô own feelings and stimulate their imaginations‚Äù

‚Äî drama, poetry, essay

1912 / Gerhart Hauptmann

‚Äúprimarily in recognition of his fruitful, varied and outstanding production in the realm of dramatic art‚Äù

‚Äî drama, novel

1913 / Rabindranath Tagore

‚Äúbecause of his profoundly sensitive, fresh and beautiful verse, by which, with consummate skill, he has made his poetic thought, expressed in his own English words, a part of the literature of the West‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, novel, drama, short story, literary criticism

1915 / Romain Rolland

‚Äúas a tribute to the lofty idealism of his literary production and to the sympathy and love of truth with which he has described different types of human beings‚Äù

‚Äî novel

1916 / Verner von Heidenstam

‚Äúin recognition of his significance as the leading representative of a new era in our literature‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, novel

1917 / Karl Adolph Gjellerup

‚Äúfor his varied and rich poetry, which is inspired by lofty ideals‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

/ Henrik Pontoppidan

‚Äúfor his authentic descriptions of present-day life in Denmark‚Äù

‚Äî novel

1919 / Carl Spitteler

‚Äúin special appreciation of his epic, Olympian Spring‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

1920 / Knut Hamsun

‚Äúfor his monumental work, Growth of the Soil‚Äù

‚Äìnovel

19211 / Anatole France

‚Äúin recognition of his brilliant literary achievements, characterized as they are by a nobility of style, a profound human sympathy, grace, and a true Gallic temperament‚Äù

‚Äî novel, poetry

1922 / Jacinto Benavente

‚Äúfor the happy manner in which he has continued the illustrious traditions of the Spanish drama‚Äù

‚Äî drama

1923 / William Butler Yeats

‚Äúfor his always inspired poetry, which in a highly artistic form gives expression to the spirit of a whole nation‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

1924 / W≈Çadys≈Çaw Reymont

‚Äúfor his great national epic, The Peasants‚Äù

‚Äî novel

1925 / George Bernard Shaw

‚Äúfor his work which is marked by both idealism and humanity, its stimulating satire often being infused with a singular poetic beauty‚Äù

‚Äî drama, literary criticism<

1926 / Grazia Deledda

‚Äúfor her idealistically inspired writings, which with plastic clarity picture the life on her native island and with depth and sympathy deal with human problems in general

‚Äî poetry, novel

1927 / Henri Bergson

‚Äúin recognition of his rich and vitalizing ideas and the brilliant skill with which they have been presented‚Äù

1928 / Sigrid Undset

‚Äúprincipally for her powerful descriptions of Northern life during the Middle Ages‚Äù

‚Äî novel

1929 / Thomas Mann

‚Äúprincipally for his great novel, Buddenbrooks, which has won steadily increased recognition as one of the classic works of contemporary literature‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, essay

1930 / Sinclair Lewis

‚Äúfor his vigorous and graphic art of description and his ability to create, with wit and humour, new types of characters‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, drama

1931 / Erik Axel Karlfeldt

‚ÄúThe poetry of Erik Axel Karlfeldt‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

1932 / John Galsworthy

‚Äúfor his distinguished art of narration, which takes its highest form in The Forsyte Saga‚Äù

‚Äî novel

1933 / Ivan Bunin

‚Äúfor the strict artistry with which he has carried on the classical Russian traditions in prose writing‚Äù

‚Äî short story, poetry, novel

1934 / Luigi Pirandello

‚Äúfor his bold and ingenious revival of dramatic and scenic art‚Äù

‚Äî drama, novel, short story

1936 / Eugene O‚ÄôNeill

‚Äúfor the power, honesty and deep-felt emotions of his dramatic works, which embody an original concept of tragedy‚Äù

‚Äî drama

1937 / Roger Martin du Gard

‚Äúfor the artistic power and truth with which he has depicted human conflict as well as some fundamental aspects of contemporary life in his novel cycle Les Thibault‚Äù

‚Äî novel

1938 / Pearl S. Buck

‚Äúfor her rich and truly epic descriptions of peasant life in China and for her biographical masterpieces‚Äù

‚Äî novel, biography

1939 / Frans Eemil Sillanp√§√§

‚Äúfor his deep understanding of his country‚Äôs peasantry and the exquisite art with which he has portrayed their way of life and their relationship with Nature‚Äù

‚Äî novel

1944 / Johannes Vilhelm Jensen

‚Äúfor the rare strength and fertility of his poetic imagination with which is combined an intellectual curiosity of wide scope and a bold, freshly creative style‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story

1945 / Gabriela Mistral

‚Äúfor her lyric poetry, which inspired by powerful emotions, has made her name a symbol of the idealistic aspirations of the entire Latin American world‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

1946 / Hermann Hesse

‚Äúfor his inspired writings, which while growing in boldness and penetration, exemplify the classical humanitarian ideals and high qualities of style‚Äù

‚Äî novel, poetry

1947 / Andr√© Gide

‚Äúfor his comprehensive and artistically significant writings, in which human problems and conditions have been presented with a fearless love of truth and keen psychological insight‚Äù

‚Äî novel, essay

1948 / T. S. Eliot

‚Äúfor his outstanding, pioneer contribution to present-day poetry‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

1949 / William Faulkner

‚Äúfor his powerful and artistically unique contribution to the modern American novel‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story

1950 / Bertrand Russell

‚Äúin recognition of his varied and significant writings in which he champions humanitarian ideals and freedom of thought‚Äù

‚Äî philosophy

1951 / P√§r Lagerkvist

‚Äúfor the artistic vigour and true independence of mind with which he endeavours in his poetry to find answers to the eternal questions confronting mankind‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, novel, short story, drama

19521 / Fran√ßois Mauriac

‚Äúfor the deep spiritual insight and the artistic intensity with which he has in his novels penetrated the drama of human life‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story

19531 / Winston Churchill

‚Äúfor his mastery of historical and biographical description as well as for brilliant oratory in defending exalted human values‚Äù

‚Äî history, essay

1954 / Ernest Hemingway

‚Äúfor his mastery of the art of narrative, most recently demonstrated in The Old Man and the Sea, and for the influence that he has exerted on contemporary style‚Äù

‚Äî novel

1955 / Halld√≥r Laxness

‚Äúfor his vivid epic power, which has renewed the great narrative art of Iceland‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, drama, poetry

1956 / Juan Ram√≥n Jim√©nez

‚Äúfor his lyrical poetry, which in Spanish language constitutes an example of high spirit and artistical purity‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

1957 / Albert Camus

‚Äúfor his important literary production, which with clear-sighted earnestness illuminates the problems of the human conscience in our times‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, drama, philosophy, essay

1958 / Boris Pasternak

‚Äúfor his important achievement both in contemporary lyrical poetry and in the field of the great Russian epic tradition‚Äù

‚Äî novel, poetry, translation

19591 / Salvatore Quasimodo

‚Äúfor his lyrical poetry, which with classical fire expresses the tragic experience of life in our own times‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

19601 / Saint-John Perse

‚Äúfor the soaring flight and the evocative imagery of his poetry, which in a visionary fashion reflects the conditions of our time‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

19611 / Ivo Andriƒá

‚Äúfor the epic force with which he has traced themes and depicted human destinies drawn from the history of his country‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story

19621 / John Steinbeck

‚Äúfor his realistic and imaginative writings, combining as they do sympathetic humour and keen social perception‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, screenplay

19631 / Giorgos Seferis

‚Äúfor his eminent lyrical writing, inspired by a deep feeling for the Hellenic world of culture‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, essay, memoirs

1964 / Jean-Paul Sartre

‚Äúfor his work, which rich in ideas and filled with the spirit of freedom and the quest for truth, has exerted a far-reaching influence on our age‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, philosophy, drama, literary criticism, screenplay

1965 / Mikhail Sholokhov

‚Äúfor the artistic power and integrity with which, in his epic of the Don, he has given expression to a historic phase in the life of the Russian people‚Äù

‚Äî novel

1966 / Shmuel Yosef Agnon

‚Äúfor his profoundly characteristic narrative art with motifs from the life of the Jewish people‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story

/ Nelly Sachs

‚Äúfor her outstanding lyrical and dramatic writing, which interprets Israel‚Äôs destiny with touching strength‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, drama

1967 / Miguel √Ångel Asturias

‚Äúfor his vivid literary achievement, deep-rooted in the national traits and traditions of Indian peoples of Latin America‚Äù

‚Äî novel, poetry

1968 / Yasunari Kawabata

‚Äúfor his narrative mastery, which with great sensibility expresses the essence of the Japanese mind‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story

1969 / Samuel Beckett

‚Äúfor his writing, which ‚Äì in new forms for the novel and drama ‚Äì in the destitution of modern man acquires its elevation‚Äù

‚Äî novel, drama, poetry

1970 / Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn

‚Äúfor the ethical force with which he has pursued the indispensable traditions of Russian literature‚Äù

‚Äî novel

1971 / Pablo Neruda

‚Äúfor a poetry that with the action of an elemental force brings alive a continent‚Äôs destiny and dreams‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

1972 / Heinrich B√∂ll

‚Äúfor his writing, which through its combination of a broad perspective on his time and a sensitive skill in characterization has contributed to a renewal of German literature‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story

1973 / Patrick White

‚Äúfor an epic and psychological narrative art, which has introduced a new continent into literature‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, drama

1974 / Eyvind Johnson

‚Äúfor a narrative art, farseeing in lands and ages, in the service of freedom‚Äù

‚Äî novel

/ Harry Martinson

‚Äúfor writings that catch the dewdrop and reflect the cosmos

‚Äî poetry, novel, drama

1975 / Eugenio Montale

‚Äúfor his distinctive poetry, which, with great artistic sensitivity, has interpreted human values under the sign of an outlook on life with no illusions‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

1976 / Saul Bellow

‚Äúfor the human understanding and subtle analysis of contemporary culture that are combined in his work‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story

1977 / Vicente Aleixandre

‚Äúfor a creative poetic writing, which illuminates man‚Äôs condition in the cosmos and in present-day society, at the same time representing the great renewal of the traditions of Spanish poetry between the wars‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

1978 / Isaac Bashevis Singer

‚Äúfor his impassioned narrative art which, with roots in a Polish-Jewish cultural tradition, brings universal human conditions to life‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, memoirs

1979 / Odysseas Elytis

‚Äúfor his poetry, which, against the background of Greek tradition, depicts with sensuous strength and intellectual clear-sightedness modern man‚Äôs struggle for freedom and creativeness‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, essay

1980 / Czes≈Çaw Mi≈Çosz

‚Äúwho with uncompromising clear-sightedness voices man‚Äôs exposed condition in a world of severe conflicts‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, essay

1981 / Elias Canetti

‚Äúfor writings marked by a broad outlook, a wealth of ideas and artistic power‚Äù

‚Äî novel, drama, memoirs, essay

1982 / Gabriel Garc√≠a M√°rquez

‚Äúfor his novels and short stories, in which the fantastic and the realistic are combined in a richly composed world of imagination, reflecting a continent‚Äôs life and conflicts‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, screenplay

1983 / William Golding

‚Äúfor his novels, which with the perspicuity of realistic narrative art and the diversity and universality of myth, illuminate the human condition in the world of today‚Äù

‚Äî novel, poetry, drama

1984 / Jaroslav Seifert

‚Äúfor his poetry, which endowed with freshness, and rich inventiveness provides a liberating image of the indomitable spirit and versatility of man‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

1985 / Claude Simon

‚Äúwho in his novel combines the poet‚Äôs and the painter‚Äôs creativeness with a deepened awareness of time in the depiction of the human condition‚Äù

‚Äî novel

1986 / Wole Soyinka

‚Äúwho in a wide cultural perspective and with poetic overtones fashions the drama of existence‚Äù

‚Äî drama, novel, poetry

1987 / Joseph Brodsky

‚Äúfor an all-embracing authorship, imbued with clarity of thought and poetic intensity‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, essay

1988 / Naguib Mahfouz

‚Äúwho, through works rich in nuance ‚Äì now clear-sightedly realistic, now evocatively ambiguous ‚Äì has formed an Arabian narrative art that applies to all mankind‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story

1989 / Camilo Jos√© Cela

‚Äúfor a rich and intensive prose, which with restrained compassion forms a challenging vision of man‚Äôs vulnerability‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story

1990 / Octavio Paz

‚Äúfor impassioned writing with wide horizons, characterized by sensuous intelligence and humanistic integrity‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, essay

1991 / Nadine Gordimer

‚Äúwho through her magnificent epic writing has ‚Äì in the words of Alfred Nobel ‚Äì been of very great benefit to humanity‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, essay

1992 / Derek Walcott

‚Äúfor a poetic oeuvre of great luminosity, sustained by a historical vision, the outcome of a multicultural commitment‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, drama

1993 / Toni Morrison

‚Äúwho in novels characterised by visionary force and poetic import, gives life to an essential aspect of American reality‚Äù

‚Äî novel

1994 / Kenzabur≈ç ≈åe

‚Äúwho with poetic force creates an imagined world, where life and myth condense to form a disconcerting picture of the human predicament today‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story

1995 / Seamus Heaney

‚Äúfor works of lyrical beauty and ethical depth, which exalt everyday miracles and the living past‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

1996 / Wis≈Çawa Szymborska

‚Äúfor poetry that with ironic precision allows the historical and biological context to come to light in fragments of human reality‚Äù

‚Äî poetry

1997 / Dario Fo

‚Äúwho emulates the jesters of the Middle Ages in scourging authority and upholding the dignity of the downtrodden‚Äù

‚Äî drama

1998 / Jos√© Saramago

‚Äúwho with parables sustained by imagination, compassion and irony continually enables us once again to apprehend an elusory reality‚Äù

‚Äî novel, drama, poetry

1999 / G√ºnter Grass

‚Äúwhose frolicsome black fables portray the forgotten face of history‚Äù

‚Äî novel, drama, poetry

2000 / Gao Xingjian

‚Äúfor an oeuvre of universal validity, bitter insights and linguistic ingenuity, which has opened new paths for the Chinese novel and drama‚Äù

‚Äî novel, drama, literary criticism

2001 / V. S. Naipaul

‚Äúfor having united perceptive narrative and incorruptible scrutiny in works that compel us to see the presence of suppressed histories‚Äù

‚Äî novel, essay

2002 / Imre Kert√©sz

‚Äúfor writing that upholds the fragile experience of the individual against the barbaric arbitrariness of history‚Äù

‚Äî novel

2003 / J. M. Coetzee

‚Äúwho in innumerable guises portrays the surprising involvement of the outsider‚Äù

‚Äî novel, essay, translation

2004 / Elfriede Jelinek

‚Äúfor her musical flow of voices and counter-voices in novels and plays that with extraordinary linguistic zeal reveal the absurdity of society‚Äôs clich√©s and their subjugating power‚Äù

‚Äî novel, drama

2005 / Harold Pinter

‚Äúwho in his plays uncovers the precipice under everyday prattle and forces entry into oppression‚Äôs closed rooms‚Äù

‚Äî drama, screenplay

2006 / Orhan Pamuk

‚Äúwho in the quest for the melancholic soul of his native city has discovered new symbols for the clash and interlacing of cultures‚Äù

‚Äî novel, screenplay, essay

2007 / Doris Lessing

‚Äúthat epicist of the female experience, who with scepticism, fire and visionary power has subjected a divided civilisation to scrutiny‚Äù

‚Äî novel, drama, poetry, short story, memoirs

2008 / J. M. G. Le Cl√©zio

‚Äúauthor of new departures, poetic adventure and sensual ecstasy, explorer of a humanity beyond and below the reigning civilization‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, essay, translation

2009 / Herta M√ºller

‚Äúwho, with the concentration of poetry and the frankness of prose, depicts the landscape of the dispossessed‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, poetry

2010 / Mario Vargas Llosa

‚Äúfor his cartography of structures of power and his trenchant images of the individual‚Äôs resistance, revolt, and defeat‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, essay, drama, memoirs

2011 / Tomas Transtr√∂mer

‚Äúbecause, through his condensed, translucent images, he gives us fresh access to reality‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, translation

2012 / Mo Yan

‚Äúwho with hallucinatory realism merges folk tales, history and the contemporary‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story

2013 / Alice Munro

‚Äúmaster of the contemporary short story‚Äù

‚Äî short story

2014 / Patrick Modiano

‚Äúfor the art of memory with which he has evoked the most ungraspable human destinies and uncovered the life-world of the occupation‚Äù

‚Äî novel

2015 / Svetlana Alexievich

‚Äúfor her polyphonic writings, a monument to suffering and courage in our time‚Äù

‚Äî history, essay

2016 / Bob Dylan

‚Äúfor having created new poetic expressions within the great American song tradition‚Äù

‚Äî poetry, songwriting

2017 / Kazuo Ishiguro

‚Äúwho, in novels of great emotional force, has uncovered the abyss beneath our illusory sense of connection with the world‚Äù

‚Äî novel

2018 / Olga Tokarczuk

‚Äúfor a narrative imagination that with encyclopedic passion represents the crossing of boundaries as a form of life‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, poetry, essay

2019 / Peter Handke

‚ÄúFor an influential work that with linguistic ingenuity has explored the periphery and the specificity of human experience.‚Äù

‚Äî novel, short story, drama
